metadata.title: Guide to Analyzing and Reporting A SINGLE TOPIC in Pol.is Conversations
metadata.purpose: Generate consistent, evidence-based reports comparing and describing the opinion dynamics of the topic and output valid JSON

criticalInstructions.instruction: Your MUST generate a JSON response that EXACTLY conforms to the schema provided below in the responseFormat section. DO NOT INCLUDE ANY OTHER TEXT or explanations outside the JSON.
DO NOT return ```json at the beginning of the response. This is not markdown. Do not end the response with ```. Your response MUST begin with { and end with }
IMPORTANT: Your response MUST follow the exact structure of the JSON example provided. Any deviation will cause errors.
Your output MUST be valid JSON. Do not use comments or trailing commas in the JSON.

term.name: differences_between_groups
term.description: Notable difference in views between groups on a single statement or related set of statements within the topic

term.name: consensus
term.description: High level of agreement across all groups on a single statement or related set of statements within the topic

criticalInstructions.instruction: In your overview, you must describe the statements on the topic, not the groups.

You must describe the narrative which emerges from the division, not just a grabbag of topics. What are the key themes, values, and ideas that emerge from the division? What is the narrative that emerges from the division?
If any group group is split, or disagrees, say the votes on statements on the topic was split or divided. Consensus means greater than 60% agreement per group across all groups.
DO NOT put any percentages in the text. DO NOT put any comment numbers in the text.

paragraph.format:
The topic [topic_name] revealed several key patterns in the conversation. Participants expressed [strong/moderate/mixed] views on [specific_aspect], with [description_of_pattern] emerging as a central theme. The discourse around [topic_name] highlighted [key_value_or_concern], particularly in relation to [related_subtopic].
Within this topic, [specific_subtopic] generated [significant/notable/minimal] discussion, with participants [agreeing/disagreeing/divided] on [specific_position]. This connected to broader themes of [overarching_theme], especially regarding [specific_aspect]. [Additional_context_if_relevant].
The conversation revealed [X] distinct perspectives on [topic_name], ranging from [perspective_1] to [perspective_2]. These viewpoints often intersected with [related_topic_or_theme], particularly when discussing [specific_aspect]. Notable areas of [consensus/division] included [specific_examples], which highlighted [pattern_or_insight].
[If consensus exists] Common ground emerged around [consensus_point], with participants across groups expressing support for [specific_position]. This alignment was particularly evident in discussions of [specific_aspect], where [description_of_consensus_pattern].
[If division exists] Key divisions centered on [point_of_contention], with varying perspectives on [specific_aspect]. These differences reflected broader [values/priorities/concerns] within the conversation, particularly regarding [specific_element].

paragraphInstructions.instruction: This format should provide a comprehensive overview of the topic, including: - Core themes and patterns - Specific areas of consensus and division - Connection to broader conversation themes - Multiple supporting citations for each claim - Clear narrative progression - Balance between specific details and broader patterns
Each major point should be supported by multiple citations, with clear connections between related statements and themes.

paragraph.length: 4-6 sentences per paragraph, with multiple paragraphs as needed to cover the topic comprehensively

criticalInstructions.instruction: There will be a variable number of groups. You must analyze how each group relates to the topic, including both direct comparisons and broader patterns.
Focus on the substantive differences in how groups understand and approach the topic, not just agreement levels.
Identify and explain any notable alignments or coalitions between groups on specific aspects of the topic.

paragraph.format:
On [topic_name], clear differences emerged between the groups' approaches and underlying values. Group [A] demonstrated [strong/moderate/mixed] [agreement/disagreement] with [specific_aspect], reflecting their emphasis on [value_or_priority]. In contrast, Group [B] approached the topic through the lens of [different_value_or_priority], leading to [strong/moderate/mixed] [agreement/disagreement] with these statements.
Group [C]'s perspective aligned more closely with [Group A/B] on [specific_aspect], particularly regarding [detailed_position]. However, they diverged notably on [different_aspect], where their [agreement/disagreement] reflected distinct [values/priorities/concerns].
[If more than three groups] The remaining groups showed varying degrees of alignment, with Groups [D] and [E] finding common ground on [shared_aspect] while diverging on [point_of_contention]. This pattern highlighted how [broader_theme_or_insight] shaped group positions on [topic_name].

paragraphInstructions.instruction: Each paragraph should: - Analyze group positions through their underlying values and priorities - Identify both expected and unexpected alignments - Connect specific positions to broader themes - Support all claims with multiple citations - Maintain focus on the specific topic while acknowledging broader patterns

paragraph.length: 3-5 paragraphs, depending on number of groups and complexity of positions

validationRules.rule: All high/low must be actual values from data
Each claim requires at least one citation
Groups must be referenced by actual group names from data, such as Group A, Group B, etc.
no percentages from comment data inserted in the text
